blocks.text: FIRST DAY — Wednesday, June 22. Left Lancaster at 5:30 A. M. Lincoln Highway to Gettysburg, to Hagerstown, Md., crossed Potomac River at Williamburg, Va., down Shenandoah Valley through Lexington as far as Abingdon (near Bristol) for night.

MARYLAND
MAXIMUM SPEED LIMIT
DUAL-LANE HIGHWAYS 55 MILES ALL OTHER ROADS 50 MILES UNLESS OTHERWISE POSTED RESIDENTIAL AND BUSINESS DISTRICTS AS POSTED OBSERVE SCHOC! R'S STOP-LAW.
At Williamsport, Md. we reach the Potomac River, and are ready to cross into West Virginia.

Crossing into Virginia, we headed for Winchester,
at the head of the Shenandoah Valley, in the heart of the apple country. Winchester, strategic point in the Civil War, was taken and retaken 72 times.

As we head down the Valley below Harrisonburg we encounter light shower shows. Here we stop for gas at the Pure Oil Village, where we spent our first night last year on our trip to Savannah.
(Note: The text is transcribed as it appears in the image.)
At the historic little town of Lexington, we inspect the beautiful campus of Washington and Lee University, and visit the chapel and tomb of Robert E. Lee.

blocks.text: SECOND DAY - Thursday, June 23. Through Bristol to Kingsport, Tenn., then southwest through rolling country to Newport, south to Great Smoky Mountains which we crossed at Mt. Sterling on gravel road, to Cherokee, through Nantahala Gorge to Murphy, N. C. for night. 253 miles - total 704 miles.
A GOOD PLACE TO STOP

Bristol, to Kingsport, to Greeneville, to Newport, where we decide to cross the Great Smokies via Mt. Sterling, instead of taking the usual tourist route across the mountains from Gatlinburg. Here we approach the Great Smokies near Cosby.

blocks.text: Our road has only a gravel surface...it twists and turns along the side of the mountains and up and down the valleys. We estimate more than 600 turns in the road. In the lower right picture, a rock slide has almost forced our road off the side of the mountain. Although we drove miles without meeting another car, we found a pocketbook containing more than $45., which we were able to return to its owner who was returning some miles beyond to look for it.
Kitty and Gordon exchange a bouquet at Cove Creek Gap, at the extreme eastern edge of the Great Smoky Mountain Park.

blocks.text: At Dellwood, we connect with a main road west from Asheville, and proceed through the Cherokee Indian Reservation, along Soco Creek to Cherokee. Indians are seen in crude cabins and along the road. High above are sections of the new Blue Ridge Parkway. Cherokee is a tourists town, where all sorts of Indian handiwork may be purchased. Some old fellows were on exhibition in full cap and feathers.

blocks.text: Southwestward from the Great Smoky Mountain National Park we soon enter the deep Nantahala Gorge, where in places there is room only for the highway, the river and the railway. The Cherokee have named it the land of the noonday sun. After passing through the Gorge, we drive a few miles north on another road, which twists along the side of the mountain, to the look-out point at left, from which we get the view above of our road emerging from the Gorge. The swinging bridge is one of several across Nantahala River.

blocks.text: THIRD DAY - Friday, June 24. Through copper-made desert at Ducktown, Tenn., to Chattanooga,into northwest corner of Georgia, into Alabama, through Birmingham, Meridian, Miss. 428 miles - total 1132 miles.
In the early morning, a last look at the Great Smokies as the sun rises behind them.
Our route touches only the southern end of the great T. V. A. power development. Here is the lake formed by Ocoee Dam. The contained water floods whole valleys.
Pauline surveys the man-made desolation in the vicinity of Ducktown and Copperhill, Tenn. where copper fumes from smelting operations have killed all vegetation over a wide area.

blocks.text: North Chattanooga (map)
North Chattanooga

Chattanooga is one of the South's greatest industrial cities. It enjoys a superb setting in the beautiful valley of the Tennessee River, surrounded by the peaks of the Cumberland Mountains.
During the Civil War, Chattanooga was considered one of the three most strategic points in the South. Its loss, as a result of the battles of Chickamauga and Lookout Mountain, in 1863 opened the way for Sherman's march to Atlanta.
Breakfast at the Cherokee Coffee Shop in Cleveland, Tenn. Circling the hugh lakes formed by the TVA dams made us feel we would never find a place for breakfast.
The generator of this steeep incline raiilway to the top of Lookout Mountain was hit by lightning the night before, so we drive the car to the top of thhhhee mountaain.
Kitty climbs steps to many of the points of interest. Maintenance of the park is excellent.

blocks.text: Lookout Mountain, scene of the “Battle Above the Clouds”, offers magnificent views of Chattanooga, Moccasin Bend of the Tennessee River, Signal Mountain and the peaks of the Cumberlands. The steep slopes rise to an elevation of 2,225 feet.

blocks.text: We circle Missionary Ridge...and cut across the northwest corner of Georgia.

Southwest through Alabama, “to Gadsden, to Birmingham, to Tuscaloosa. In Alabama, we ran through no less than seven separate and distinct heavy rainstorms. No sooner would one subside than far in the distance dark, heavy clouds would signal the approach of another storm.”
We take a side trip through Alabama City to see 90 ft. Noccalula Falls.

blocks.text: An excellent dinner at "Pug's", across the street from the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa.
Typical road in Alabama...gently rolling country-side with dense forests of pine.

FOURTH DAY - Saturday, June 25. To Jackson, Miss., to Vicksburg, across Mississippi River into Louisiana, to Monroe and Shreveport, entered Texas (1480 miles), as far as Terrell for night.
493 miles – total 1625 miles.
Somewhere in Mississippi - we see here the most emaciated animal trying to pull a broken down cart on which the wheels refuse to turn.
Armstrong's plant in Jackson, Miss., where we visit John Martin, former Lancastrian, who is assistant manager of the plant.

blocks.text: We iiinspectspect the capitol of Mississippi at Jackson. We inspect the capitol of Mississiissippipppi pi api aat Ja Jackson..

On the bluffs overlooking the river at Vicksburg we have our first view of the Mississippi. We pay toll on $1.70 to cross the bridge shown right.
Vicksburg was captured by Union forces under Gen. Grant after a siege of several months. The city occupied an important position, difficult of assault. Its capture cleared the Mississippi, split the Confederacy, and cut off the supplies it had been receiving from Europe through Mexican ports. With Vicksburg secured, Union troops could march on Chattanooga. There the city of Vicksburg was surrendered by Gen. Pemberton, with about 30,000 troops on July 3, 1863.

blocks.text: The first thing we see in Louisiana, after crossing the Mississippi is the Last Chance Tavern, which is fairly typical of much of that state through which we drove. The eastern part of the state is flat, swampy, and inhabited mostly by negroes who live in the poorest manner imaginable. West of Monroe, the land appears richer and the living conditions improve.

Texas, at last! after driving 1,488 miles from Lancaster. We have dinner at Gladewater, note the oil wells in this section of eastern Texas, leave rolling country to enter flat plains as we drive to Terrell, the last hour of the trip after dark.
One of our firrirst stops in Texas is to try a glass One of our first stops in Texas is to try a glass one of cherry cider. cherrierryryy chilldder..

blocks.text: FIFTH DAY - Sunday, June 26. Through Dallas and Ft. Worth, to Abilene, and finally Big Spring in mid-afternoon. 331 miles - total 1956 miles.

The Texas & Pacific Railroad parallels the highway along the 333 miles drive from Dallas to Ft. Worth. Tourist camps, cottages, drive-in theatres, hamburger stands, restaurants, night spots, gas stations are found profusion.
Beyond Ft. Worth we rise to a high plateau. Cattle country. There are massive white clouds and a clear invigorating breeze without a trace of humidity. Most of the vegetation is of scrub variety.
Approach to Ft. Worth.
At the banks of the Brazos River, where it is claimed catfish as large as 63 pounds have been caught. We don't argue about it.

blocks.text: SIXTH, SEVENTH AND EIGHTH DAYS – MONDAY, TUESDAY and WEDNESDAY, JUNE 27, 28 and 29. Attended National Convention of American Business Clubs in Big Spring. Drove only 12 miles.

Our rooms on the fourth floor of Crawford Hotel. The city hall is in the foreground.
The room's location and details are mentioned, with a focus on their position relative to the hotel and nearby landmarks such as the city hall. This information provides context for understanding where these individuals were staying during their visit or stay at the Crawford Hotel.
The main street, Big Spring, Texas.
The municipal auditorium where the business sessions of the Convention are held. Gordon is elected to the National Executive Board.
Real cacti as a touch of the finger soon convinces.

blocks.text: NEW MEXICO STATE LINE
NEW MEXICO STATE LINE

The Texas-New Mexico line with Rabbit Ear Mountain, which is visible for 30 miles, in the background. The large picture gives a good example of the topography of this part of New Mexico - prairies with occasional large mountains, like carbuncles growing out of the land. These mountains increase in size and frequency as we approach Colorado. There are few people and towns are small and far spaced. Herds of cattle, like tiny insects, roam over a wide expanse.

blocks.text: Miles away, as we approach Capulin Mountain, we see the road to the summit winding around on the side. Capulin is said to be one of the most perfect extinct volcanos in America. The hugh crater is 1,450 feet in diameter. The last violent eruption occurred about 2000 years ago. We climb to the top in spite of threats of rain which might make the gravel road hazardous.

The first night of our trip home is spent at Raton, N. M. Here, at dusk, we shop for souvenirs.

blocks.text: TENTH DAY - Friday, July 1. From Raton into Colorado, to Trinidad, to Walsenburg, drive along Sangre de Cristo range to Arkansas River, to Royal Gorge, up Phantom Canyon to gold mining district, along Gold Camp Road to Colorado Springs. 282 miles - total for trip 2708 miles.
COLORADO STATE LINE LAS ANIMAS CO.
LAS ANIMAS CO.

In the early morning, we climb Raton Pass, 7,834 feet, and suddenly – as we reach the Colorado line the full majesty of the Rocky Mountains lies before us. To the west, as far as we can see, lofty peaks rise one after another, many of them capped with snow.

blocks.text:
At Walsenburg, Colo., we decide to follow the gravel road,
well off the beaten tourist path, which runs in a north-
western direction at the foot of the Sangre de Cristo Range.
Ahead is Greenhorn Mountain, 12,334 feet, which we pass to
the west. At Walsenburg, we can see faintly in the distance
the outlines of Pikes Peak, almost 100 miles away.

blocks.text:
The Royal Gorge, one seen is never forgotten. The first reaction on looking into the awe-some gorge is to step away from it. More than a thousand feet below the River rushes along its twisting course, contained by monstrous layers of solid rock walls. The picture may be better appreciated when we realize it is almost twice as deep as the Washington Monument is high.
The train tracks are those of the Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad on this sight-seeing trip between Denver and Salt Lake City, a trip which requires twenty-three hours. Trains stop here to permit passengers to alight for ten minutes in order to obtain a better view.
The cogwheel railroad, shown at lower left, connects the debths of the canyon with the suspension bridge and lookouts far above.

The Royal Gorge, one seen is never forgotten. The first reaction on looking into the awe-some gorge is to step away from it. More than a thousand feet below the River rushes along its twisting course, contained by monstrous layers of solid rock walls. The picture may be better appreciated when we realize it is almost twice as deep as the Washington Monument is high.
The train tracks are those of the Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad on this sight-seeing trip between Denver and Salt Lake City, a trip which requires twenty-three hours. Trains stop here to permit passengers to alight for ten minutes in order to obtain a better view.
The cogwheel railroad, shown at lower left, connects the debths of the canyon with the suspension bridge and lookouts far above.

blocks.text: From Cripple Creek, we head for Colorado Springs on the Gold Camp Road, one of the West's most exciting drives. Much of it is on the crest of the mountains, with deep, narrow fills, without protection, over the gorges. There are a number of tunnels. To add to our concern, rain fell during most of the drive.

blocks.text: Entrance to the Garden of the Gods, with a cloud hovering over Pikes Peak in the background.

After dinner and arrangements for the night being made in Colorado Springs we decide to visit the Garden of the Gods, a few miles outside the city. Here hugh sandstone spires form an impressive sight. Indians in bygone times are supposed to have come here to worship.

blocks.text: ELEVENTH DAY - Saturday, July 2. Drive from Colorado Springs to Denver, west from Denver to climb Mt. Evans, then over Berthoud Pass to Grand Lake, enter Rocky Mountain National Park, drive on mountain peaks to Estes Park, through Big Thompson Canyon, to Loveland, to Greeley, Colo. for night. 338 miles - total for trip 3046 miles.
From Colorado Springs, we head seventy miles north to Denver, and bid good by to Pikes Peak, which we decide to forego climbing in favor of loftier Mt. Evans.
A stop for fresh fruit just outside Denver.

blocks.text: The Theatre of the Red Rocks, just west of Denver, which in its natural setting seats more than 9000, with acoustics that are world famous. Kitty speaking in a normal voice on the stage can be heard distinctly by Gordon on the last row of seats.
West from mile high Denver, snow capped peaks once again lie ahead. This is the main road to Idaho Springs and the Rocky Mountain National Park.

blocks.text:
The climb up Mt. Evans (14260 ft.) on the highest auto road in the United States, perhaps the most outstanding event of the whole trip.
A good, hard surfaced road begins at Idaho Springs, about thirty five miles west of Denver. We drive 23 miles each way to experience the whole gamut of thrills that go with mountain driving.

This is a far as we can go. Although the road winds for another

two hours previously to try for the top and who awaits inconsol-
ately for his return. We decide not to try it.

blocks.text: Shadow Mountain Lake.

This region is the location of the Grand Lake-Big Thompson water diversion project, now under construction by the United States Government, using federal funds. A tunnel 13 miles long has been built under the Continental Divide to carry water from the western slope to the eastern in order to provide additional water for irrigated farming and for generating electric power. The original estimate for the project was $44 millions; more than $100 million have been expended; and it is now believed $200 millions will be needed to complete the project. An example of Government planning!

blocks.text: Longmont
To Nederland.
Boulder.

Rocky Mountain National Park embraces an area of 405 square miles. Rugged mountains, dense forests and crystal-clear lakes abound. Within its boundaries are 14 massive, snow-capped peaks more than 13,000 feet high. Trail Ridge Road, America's highest continuous automobile highway, runs for 40 miles through the Park,'11 miles are above the 11,000 foot timber line and 4 miles are above 12,000 feet.
We enter Rocky Mountain National Park only a mile or so from Grand Lake. Fee $1.

blocks.text:
The long road emerges above timber line. The emerald green trees emerge as the forest becomes a sea of vibrant colors, with hues ranging from deep greens to bright yellows and oranges. This natural spectacle is truly breathtaking, showcasing nature's beauty at its finest.
As we continue our journey through this stunning landscape, it feels like stepping into another world where time stands still. The air is crisp and clean, filled with the scent of pine needles and wildflowers that bloom along the path. It's a moment to pause and appreciate all that surrounds us – from towering trees reaching for the sky to delicate flowers dancing in gentle breezes.
This journey through nature reminds us of our connection to Earth and its ever-changing beauty. As we walk among these majestic creatures, it becomes clear why so many people find solace and inspiration here. It's a reminder that even amidst chaos or uncertainty, there is always something beautiful waiting just around the corner – if only you take time to look.
So let us embrace this journey together, exploring what lies beyond timber line with open hearts and curious minds. Let us cherish these moments of peace and wonder as we continue our quest for knowledge about ourselves and our planet.
Plenty of snow here.

Just before we descend to Estes Park, we see our road far below on a number of levels. In the extreme distance, beyond the far range of mountains, may be glimpsed the Great Plains, more than forty miles away.

Beyond Estes Park, we enter Big Thompson Canyon,
where the river and road lie below hugh walls of rock for a distance of a dozen miles.

pages.path: 1949 Big Spring A.B/1949 Big Spring A-B-62.jpg

blocks.text:
TWELFTH DAY - Sunday, July 3. From Greeley, Colo., through southwestern corner of Nebraska,
into Kansas, across Kansas to St. Joseph, Mo. (crossed Missouri River here), to Cameron, Mo.,
for night. 607 miles - total 3653 miles for trip.
We are now well out of the mountains and all of us feel the sweet call of home. We drive the intervening 1,700 miles in three days flat.
A stop for gas at Brush. Colo. We are in the Great Plains but the elevation is still more than 4,000 feet. Al is declaring emphatically: "I have not been asleep for the last half hour".
We stop a moment to get our pictures on a sign with Nebraska as we cut across the southwestern corner of the state headed for Kansas.
In Kansas, a sign marks the Geographic Center of the United States.

blocks.text: We cross the Missouri River at St. Joseph, Mo., in late evening, fail to secure accommodations on account of the 4th of July week-end, so we drive into Missouri as far as Cameron.
Kitty can't resist the urge to become better acquainted with so much wheat.

THIRTEENTH DAY - Monday, July 4. Across Missouri to Hannibal, crossed Mississippi River into Illinois, to Springfield, to Decatur, into Indiana, through Indianapolis, to a point just over the Ohio line for the night. 562 miles - total 4215 miles for trip.

blocks.text: FOURTEENTH DAY — Tuesday, July 5. Through Ohio to Springfield, to Columbus, to Wheeling, W. Va., where we crossed the Ohio River, into Pennsylvania, to Washington, to the Turnpike, to Carlisle, to Harrisburg, and home. 533 miles - grand total for trip 4748 miles.

The State of Ohio makes more provision for the comfort of travelers than other other state which we visit. Here is one of many roadside parks, with cool shade trees, running water, picnic tables and clean toilet facilities. We are in hill country again, at last!
At Columbus, we visit Kitty's sister, Helen, Hellen, and Dick Andes.

blocks.text: This old suspension bridge spans the Ohio River at Wheeling. Failure by the state to heed repeated requests for a new bridge, recently led the indignant citizens of Wheeling to threaten to secede from the glorious state of West Virginia.

From Washington, Pa., we head north to the Pennsylv-
ylvania Turnpike for a quick last leg of our trip.
A final bite to eat as darkness closes in. We reach home after midnight.
End - Trip to Texas.
